qas.question: When was the first lighting used on an airport?
When did approach lighting come into use?
What indicated the proper direction and angle of descent?
When was the slope-line approach system introduced?
What consisted of two rows of lights that formed a funnel, indicating an aircraft's position on the glidescope?
When was the first  lighting with flash intervals used on an airplane?

plausible_answers.text: colours and flash intervals of these lights

qas.question: What was standardized by airports in the 1920's?

plausible_answers.text: two rows of lights that formed a funnel indicating an aircraft's position on the glideslope

qas.question: What did the flash interval system consist of?

plausible_answers.text: an aircraft's position on the glideslope

qas.question: What do light colors indicate on an aircraft?
What group standardized additional indication lights?

context: The first lighting used on an airport was during <b5_0>the <a0_0>latter part of the 1920s<b5_0/><a0_0/>; in the <a1_0>1930s<a1_0/> <a2_0>approach lighting<a2_0/> came into use. These indicated the proper direction and angle of descent. The <b6_0>colours and flash intervals of these lights<b6_0/> became standardized under <b9_0>the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO)<b9_0/>. In the <a3_0>1940s<a3_0/>, the <a4_0>slope-line approach system<a4_0/> was introduced. This consisted of <b7_0>two rows of lights that formed a funnel indicating <b8_0>an aircraft's position on the glideslope<b8_0/><b7_0/>. Additional lights indicated incorrect altitude and direction.
